conditions.name: Common Cold
conditions.overview: The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, primarily affecting the nose and throat. It is one of the most frequent illnesses, with adults experiencing 2-3 colds per year on average. While uncomfortable, colds are generally self-limiting and resolve within 7-10 days.
redFlags: Fever above 101.3°F (38.5°C) lasting more than 3 days
Symptoms persisting beyond 10 days without improvement
Severe headache or facial pain (possible sinusitis)
Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath

recommendedPlants.usage: Take at the first sign of cold symptoms. May reduce duration and severity when taken early.

references.title: Echinacea for preventing and treating the common cold
references.authors: Karsch-Völk M, Barrett B, Kiefer D, et al.

conditions.name: Insomnia
conditions.overview: Insomnia is characterized by difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking too early and being unable to return to sleep. It can be acute (short-term) or chronic (lasting three months or longer). Chronic insomnia affects approximately 10-15% of adults and can significantly impact quality of life, mood, and daytime functioning.
symptoms: Difficulty falling asleep despite being tired
Waking too early in the morning
redFlags: Symptoms of sleep apnea (loud snoring, gasping for air during sleep)
Persistent insomnia despite good sleep hygiene
Significant daytime impairment affecting work or safety
Use of alcohol or sedatives to sleep
Restless legs or periodic limb movements

recommendedPlants.usage: Take 300-600mg of valerian root extract 30 minutes to 2 hours before bedtime. May improve sleep quality and reduce time to fall asleep.

references.title: Valerian for sleep: a systematic review and meta-analysis
references.authors: Fernández-San-Martín MI, Masa-Font R, Palacios-Soler L, et al.

conditions.name: Mild Anxiety
conditions.overview: Mild anxiety involves feelings of worry, nervousness, or unease that are disproportionate to the actual threat or situation. While some anxiety is normal and adaptive, persistent or excessive anxiety can interfere with daily activities. Mild anxiety is distinguished from anxiety disorders by its lower intensity and lesser impact on functioning.
redFlags: Panic attacks with severe physical symptoms
Anxiety interfering significantly with work, school, or relationships
Avoidance of normal activities due to anxiety
Severe physical symptoms (chest pain, difficulty breathing)

recommendedPlants.usage: Take 120-240mg of kavalactones daily for short-term relief of mild anxiety. Not recommended for long-term use due to potential liver concerns.

plants.description: Echinacea purpurea is a flowering plant native to North America, widely recognized for its immune-supporting properties. The plant features distinctive purple-pink petals surrounding a spiky central cone. Traditionally used by Native American tribes for various ailments, echinacea is now one of the most popular herbal supplements for immune health.

images.altText: Dried echinacea root showing fibrous structure
images.caption: Echinacea root - primary medicinal part

preparationMethods.instructions: Use 1:5 ratio of dried root to 40% alcohol. Macerate for 2-4 weeks, shaking daily.
preparationMethods.duration: At first sign of cold, continue for 7-10 days maximum
preparationMethods.notes: Most commonly used preparation. Take at onset of symptoms for best results.

preparationMethods.instructions: Steep 1-2 grams of dried root or aerial parts in hot water for 10-15 minutes.
preparationMethods.notes: Less concentrated than tincture but still effective.
Ensure product is standardized to contain active compounds.

contraindications.description: May stimulate immune system and potentially worsen autoimmune conditions such as multiple sclerosis, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, or others.
Limited safety data during pregnancy. Some studies suggest safety, but consult healthcare provider.
Generally considered safe for children over 2 years. Not recommended for infants.
Avoid in individuals allergic to plants in the Asteraceae family (ragweed, marigolds, daisies).

harvestingGuidance.harvestSeason: Roots: fall after 3-4 years growth. Aerial parts: during flowering (summer).
harvestingGuidance.sustainabilityNotes: Cultivate rather than wild-harvest. Plant is easy to grow and readily available. Wild populations should not be harvested.

references.title: Echinacea for preventing and treating the common cold
references.authors: Karsch-Völk M, Barrett B, Kiefer D, et al.

references.title: Evaluation of echinacea for prevention and treatment of the common cold: a meta-analysis
references.authors: Shah SA, Sander S, White CM, et al.

plants.description: Valeriana officinalis is a perennial flowering plant native to Europe and Asia, now naturalized in North America. Known for its sedative and anxiolytic properties, valerian has been used for centuries to promote sleep and reduce anxiety. The root has a distinctive, pungent odor often described as earthy or musky. Despite the smell, it is one of the most well-researched herbal sleep aids.

images.altText: Valerian plant with clusters of small pink-white flowers
images.caption: Valeriana officinalis in bloom

images.altText: Fresh valerian root showing characteristic appearance
images.caption: Valerian root - the primary medicinal part

phytochemicals.name: Valerenic acid
phytochemicals.proposedMechanism: GABA-A receptor modulation, increases GABA availability in synaptic cleft

phytochemicals.name: Valepotriates
phytochemicals.proposedMechanism: Sedative effects, though unstable and may degrade during processing

phytochemicals.name: Isovaleric acid
phytochemicals.proposedMechanism: Contributes to sedative effects; responsible for characteristic odor

preparationMethods.instructions: Use standardized valerian root extract (0.3-0.8% valerenic acid).
preparationMethods.frequency: Once daily, 30 minutes to 2 hours before bedtime
preparationMethods.duration: Can be used for several weeks; effectiveness may increase with continued use
preparationMethods.notes: Most common and well-studied preparation. Allow 2-4 weeks for full effects.

preparationMethods.instructions: Steep 2-3 grams of dried valerian root in hot water for 10-15 minutes.
preparationMethods.frequency: 1-2 times daily, with one dose before bedtime
preparationMethods.notes: Has strong odor. May be combined with other relaxing herbs like lemon balm or chamomile.
Alcohol-based tinctures preserve valepotriates better than aqueous extracts.

contraindications.description: Insufficient safety data during pregnancy. Avoid use during pregnancy and lactation.
Not recommended for children under 3 years. Use with caution in older children.
Rare reports of hepatotoxicity. Use with caution in individuals with liver disease.
May potentiate sedative effects of anesthesia. Discontinue at least 2 weeks before surgery.
May cause drowsiness. Do not operate heavy machinery or drive until you know how it affects you. Avoid combining with alcohol or other sedatives.

harvestingGuidance.harvestSeason: Fall of second year, after aerial parts have died back
harvestingGuidance.sustainabilityNotes: Easily cultivated. Prefers moist, rich soil. Wild harvest should be sustainable and from abundant populations only.

references.title: Valerian for sleep: a systematic review and meta-analysis
references.authors: Fernández-San-Martín MI, Masa-Font R, Palacios-Soler L, et al.

references.title: Valerian extract and valerenic acid are partial agonists of the 5-HT5a receptor in vitro
references.authors: Dietz BM, Mahady GB, Pauli GF, et al.

plants.description: Piper methysticum is a plant native to the South Pacific islands, where it has been used ceremonially and medicinally for over 3,000 years. The root contains kavalactones, compounds with anxiolytic and muscle-relaxant properties. Kava has gained popularity in Western countries as a natural remedy for anxiety, though concerns about potential liver toxicity have led to restrictions in some countries.

images.altText: Kava plant showing heart-shaped leaves in tropical setting
images.caption: Piper methysticum growing in natural habitat

images.altText: Kava root showing woody, fibrous structure
images.caption: Kava root - contains anxiolytic kavalactones

phytochemicals.name: Kavain
phytochemicals.proposedMechanism: GABA-A receptor modulation, voltage-gated sodium channel blockade

preparationMethods.duration: Short-term use only (up to 4-8 weeks) due to liver safety concerns
preparationMethods.notes: Water-based or aqueous-ethanol extracts preferred. Avoid acetone or ethanol-only extracts.

preparationMethods.instructions: Traditional preparation: pound or grind root, mix with cold water, strain through cloth.
preparationMethods.notes: Traditional aqueous preparation may have better safety profile than alcoholic extracts.

contraindications.description: Contraindicated in individuals with liver disease or history of liver problems. Rare but serious cases of hepatotoxicity reported.

references.title: Kava and the risk of hepatotoxicity

contraindications.description: Not recommended during pregnancy or lactation due to insufficient safety data.
May inhibit CYP450 enzymes, particularly CYP2D6 and CYP3A4. Can interact with many medications.
Discontinue at least 2 weeks before surgery due to potential interaction with anesthesia.
May cause drowsiness. Do not combine with alcohol, benzodiazepines, or other CNS depressants. Monitor liver function if using regularly. Avoid driving or operating machinery.

harvestingGuidance.harvestSeason: Roots harvested after 3-5 years of growth
harvestingGuidance.sustainabilityNotes: Cultivated commercially in Pacific islands. Wild harvest threatens natural populations. Purchase only from ethical, sustainable sources. Plant is difficult to cultivate outside tropical regions.

references.title: Kava for the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder (K-GAD): study protocol for a randomized controlled trial
references.authors: Sarris J, Stough C, Teschke R, et al.
